title: Gabbard Arranges Trump Call With FBI Agents After Georgia Election Center Search
summary: Tulsi Gabbard’s role in brokering the call and President Trump’s decision to directly press frontline agents on the inquiry are outside the bounds of typical procedure, The Times has learned.

title: Colombia’s President, an Outspoken Trump Critic, Heads to the White House
summary: President Gustavo Petro of Colombia and President Trump have had a tense relationship that escalated into threats by Mr. Trump, before easing. Anything could happen at their Feb. 3 meeting.

title: A 1987 Proposal Could Help Hold ICE to Account for Constitutional Violations
summary: A proposal in a 1987 law review article could address a gap that makes it all but impossible to sue federal officials for violating the Constitution.

title: Small Businesses in Minneapolis Serve a City in Crisis. ‘This Is Our New Normal.’
summary: In Minneapolis and St. Paul, business owners work to lift up a community that has been roiled by the presence of thousands of immigration agents.

title: Protesters Press Target to Take a Stand Against ICE Crackdown in Minneapolis
summary: The Minnesota-based retail chain has avoided criticizing anyone, even after federal agents detained two employees at a local store. Its new C.E.O. faces pressure to do more.

title: Trump Administration Sued Over Ban on Immigration From 75 Countries
summary: The Trump administration says these immigrants take welfare intended for Americans, which the lawsuit says is an “unsupported and demonstrably false claim.”

title: Rafah Crossing in Gaza Reopens, Another Step for Fragile Cease-Fire
summary: Israel and Egypt had disagreed for months about how to resume operations at the Rafah border crossing, which has been largely closed since May 2024.

title: What to Know About the Rafah Border Crossing in Gaza
summary: The only crossing that connects Gaza with Egypt has reopened. The move will allow residents to leave for medical care or return to homes and families in the territory.

title: Best and Worst Moments From the 2026 Grammys
summary: Addison Rae tapped into 2000s pop energy, Justin Bieber stripped things down and Bad Bunny got choked up at the 68th annual awards.

title: Trump Assails Grammys and Threatens to Sue Trevor Noah Over Epstein Joke
summary: President Trump declared the awards ceremony “virtually unwatchable” and accused Mr. Noah of defamation over a joke he made that appeared to tie the president to Jeffrey Epstein.

title: How the Supreme Court Secretly Made Itself Even More Secretive
summary: Amid calls to increase transparency and revelations about the court’s inner workings, the chief justice imposed nondisclosure agreements on clerks and employees.

title: Why The Times Is Expanding Its Supreme Court Coverage
summary: How four reporters are examining the most secretive branch of government — and the nine justices who shape the law.

title: The Government Published Dozens of Nude Photos in the Epstein Files
summary: The photos, which showed young women or possibly teenagers with their faces visible, were largely removed after The New York Times began notifying the Justice Department.

title: How Trump Appears in the Epstein Files
summary: The New York Times found more than 5,300 files with references to Mr. Trump and related terms. They include salacious and unverified claims, as well as documents that had already been made public.

title: The Major Business Names in the Epstein Files
summary: Documents referencing prominent executives like Elon Musk, Howard Lutnick and Bill Gates underscored the wide web of boldfaced names tied to Jeffrey Epstein.

title: The Wonder Drug That’s Plaguing Sports
summary: Ostarine held the promise of profound medical treatments. Something unexpected happened on the way to F.D.A. approval.

title: Punxsutawney Phil Sees His Shadow on Groundhog Day, Predicting Longer Winter for U.S.
summary: The supposedly meteorologically gifted rodent saw his shadow, suggesting several more weeks of winter. (Forecasters agreed, at least for this week.)

title: Fear and Anger Grow as Thousands Remain Without Power in the South
summary: More than 30 people have died across three Southern states in connection with last week’s storm, and thousands remain without power.

title: Snow, Ice, Parking Hell: It’s a Tough Winter to Be a New York City Mover
summary: Even in summer, moving crews have to contend with walk-up apartments, double-parking and sofas that won’t fit through narrow hallways. It’s a lot worse right now.

title: The Effects of Tariffs, One Year Into Trump’s Trade Experiment
summary: Five charts show the impact on the economy after a year of sweeping trade changes by the Trump administration.

title: The Key to Managing Tariffs: Be Big and Have the President’s Ear
summary: Several large American manufacturers are thriving despite the threat of higher costs. Smaller ones are struggling.

title: Westminster 2026: Yes, Some Show Dogs Still Have Day Jobs
summary: Nick, a Tibetan spaniel, is a therapy dog at a senior living center in Washington. He is one of several champion show dogs that have busy lives outside of the competition.

title: These Pictures of Westminster Dogs Are Best in Show
summary: For nearly a century, photographers for The New York Times have captured an annual extravaganza that is a red carpet gala, sporting event and fashion show rolled into one.

title: Move Fast, but Obey the Rules: China’s Vision for Dominating A.I.
summary: Beijing wants to lead the world in developing cutting-edge artificial intelligence, but it also wants companies to adhere to an increasingly complex set of rules.

title: ‘Today’ Anchor Savannah Guthrie’s Mother Is Missing, Authorities Say
summary: The authorities said on Monday that they were investigating the disappearance of Nancy Guthrie, 84, who was last seen on Saturday near her home in Tucson, Ariz., as a crime.

title: Games On
summary: We preview the Winter Olympics.

title: Countries Have Long Tested Their Own Athletes for Doping. That Could Soon Change.
summary: After Chinese swimmers won Olympic gold in 2021 despite having tested positive for a banned substance, the World Anti-Doping Agency is considering whether to have an independent body handle testing before major events.

title: We Were Top Homeland Security Lawyers. You Can’t Wish Away the Fourth Amendment.
summary: Forcibly entering homes with only administrative warrants is unconstitutional.

title: After His Democratic Victory in Texas, a New Working-Class Star Rises
summary: Taylor Rehmet, a machinist and union leader, pulled off a stunning State Senate win in Fort Worth and its suburbs. He is among several political outsiders seeking office.

title: After Weeks of Rancor, a Glimmer of Hope in N.Y.C. Nurses’ Strike
summary: Nearly 15,000 workers have been off the job at some of New York’s top hospitals for three weeks, but signs of progress have emerged in negotiations.

title: Erfan Soltani, Iranian Protester Who Reportedly Faced a Death Sentence, Is Released on Bail
summary: Mr. Soltani, 26, was arrested last month as Iran brutally repressed anti-government demonstrations.

title: Man, 83, Tricked by Scammers, Gets 21 Years to Life for Killing Uber Driver
summary: Scammers on the phone had threatened to kill Wiliam J. Brock if he didn’t hand over $12,000 just as Lo-Letha Toland-Hall, an Uber driver, came to his house to pick up a package.
